text: Monica you're reporting that states
across the country are releasing
prisoners early as a cost-cutting method
on the face of it it seems a little
extreme how widespread is this actually
about half the states in the country are
looking at ways to do this and some of
them would argue to you that this isn't
just about saving money this is about
doing the right thing that that that
their prison populations had grown and
grown and grown and that this is
actually the right moment to shrink them
but of course along the way they're
trying to save money and what kind of
reaction has there been well there's
been mixed reaction but in some states
there's been pretty intense opposition
to it a few places have had something
happen where a particular prisoner has
gotten out and people are upset about
that other places there there have been
lawsuits there even in Michigan their
prosecutors who are filing suit to try
to stop some of these people from being
released so you find the prosecutor the
local prosecutors filing suit against
you know essentially the state is there
an expectation that this will become an
even bigger trend or have the troubles
actually discouraged other states from
joining in no I think we're going to see
more and more of this I think that the
fact is that even as we've seen the the
economy recover somewhat for somewhat
for individuals we're seeing the exact
opposite for states this is times are
actually getting worse for state budgets
and this is one big place where they
spend money give us one example for for
instance you write about Michigan how
big of a problem is this in Michigan
well in Michigan they were seeing the
population grow and grow and grow
meanwhile as we all know the budget in
Michigan has struggled dramatically for
a number of reasons and so they're
really trying to make an active effort
to cut the number of prisoners in fact
the governor this year is proposing
7,500 fewer prisoners again this is
after they've already made cuts last
year and so this is where you see the
pushback from local prosecutors who say
well wait a second we want to save money
but I'm not sure this particular person
or that particular person is the right
one to be getting out
one last question for you Monica just
give us a sense of how serious the
overcrowding is in these prisons well I
think overcrowding has always been an
issue as long been an issue but I think
now the issue that's really come out is
an effort to save money by even closing
prisons trying to actually shrink that
whole infrastructure in Michigan you see
prisons closing last year more proposed
for this year so if you cut the
population you can cut the number of
prisons that are open and you can cut
that much staff if this is an enormous
amount of money that they can save
